title: How to Make Kielbasa and Cabbage Soup

methods.name: Making Savory Kielbasa and Cabbage Soup

steps.headline: Melt the butter in a large skillet.
steps.description: Set a skillet on the stove. Add the butter, then turn the heat up to medium. Stir the butter occasionally so that it coats the bottom of the pan.

steps.headline: Add the kielbasa, onions, and celery.
steps.description: Cook them, stirring occasionally, until the kielbasa browns. This will take about 3 to 5 minutes.

steps.headline: Combine all of the ingredients, except for the potatoes, in a large saucepan.
steps.description: Transfer the browned kielbasa, onions, and celery into a large saucepan. Add the shredded cabbage, sliced carrots, bay leaf, and thyme. Pour in the white vinegar, beef broth, and water. Stir to combine. Hold off on the potatoes for now. You can use prepared beef broth or you can make you own using bouillon cubes and hot water. Typically, it is 1 cube per 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water, but check the package to be certain.

steps.headline: Cook the soup for 1 hour.
steps.description: Bring the soup to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. Immediately reduce the heat to low and bring the soup to a simmer. Cover the pot with a lid, and allow the soup to cook for 1 hour.

steps.headline: Add the potatoes.
steps.description: Continue cooking the soup until the potatoes turn tender. This will take about 20 minutes, depending on how small you cut the potatoes.

steps.headline: Season and serve the soup.
steps.description: Once the potatoes are cooked through, give the soup a taste. Season it with some salt and pepper to your liking, then serve it with a sprinkle of dill.

methods.name: Making Red Kielbasa and Cabbage Soup

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a large saucepan over medium heat.
steps.description: As the oil heats, you can start cutting the onions, carrots, potatoes, and kielbasa. The paprika and tomatoes will give this soup a slight, reddish color.

steps.headline: Cook the onions, carrots, potatoes, and kielbasa until the onions turn soft.
steps.description: This will take about 5 minutes or so. Stir the ingredients often with a wooden spoon as they cook. This ensures that everything heats evenly.

steps.headline: Add in the rest of your ingredients.
steps.description: Toss in the tomatoes and cabbage. Pour in the beef stock. Add in the parsley, sugar, paprika, and pepper. Give everything a good stir to combine. You can use store bought beef stock, or you can prepare you own using hot water and bouillon cubes. Typically, it is 1 cube of bouillon per 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water, but check the packaging to be sure.

steps.headline: Bring the soup to a boil, then simmer it for 20 minutes.
steps.description: Cover the saucepan and bring the soup to a boil. Once it starts to boil, lower the heat to medium low. Let the soup simmer for 20 minutes. Keep the saucepan covered during this time. The soup is ready when the vegetables turn tender.

steps.headline: Serve the soup.
steps.description: Once the vegetables are tender, ladle the soup out into serving bowls. Serve it while it is still hot.

steps.headline: Prepare the sauerkraut.
steps.description: Take the sauerkraut out of the jar. Transfer it to a strainer, and rinse it under cool water. Allow any excess liquid to drain away, then set the sauerkraut aside. This soup will be a little more tart than the typical kielbasa and cabbage soup. You can make this soup using kielbasa instead of spareribs. Cut the kielbasa into slices.

steps.headline: Combine the broth, ribs, bay leaves, peppercorns, carrots, and dried mushrooms in a large saucepan.
steps.description: Hold off on the sauerkraut and sugar for right now. If you can't find any prepared beef broth, you can make your own by dissolving 2 large bouillon cubes in 4 cups (950 milliliters) of hot water. For best flavor, use wild forest mushrooms. If you are using kielbasa, add it in now.

steps.headline: Simmer the soup for 1 hour and 30 minutes.
steps.description: Bring the soup to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. Reduce the heat to low. Simmer the soup, uncovered, for 1 hour and 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Add 4 more cups (950 milliliters) of water.
steps.description: If you used whole, dried mushrooms, take them out of the pot, cut them into strips, then add them back in. If they are already sliced, you don't need to do this.

steps.headline: Heat the sugar over medium heat.
steps.description: Pour the sugar into a separate saucepan. Heat it over medium heat until it starts to caramelize. This will help sweeten the soup and take away some of the tartness. If you don't want to do this, you can skip this step.

steps.headline: Add the sauerkraut and sugar to the soup.
steps.description: Give the soup a stir, then let it return to a simmer. Cover the pot with a lid, and let the soup cook for 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Slice the ribs up.
steps.description: Take the ribs out of the pot with a pair of tongs. Pull the meat off of the bones using two forks. Cut the meat into bite-sized pieces and return them to the soup. Discard the bones. If you are using kielbasa instead, skip this step.

steps.headline: Serve the soup while it is still hot.
steps.description: Once your have the meat back in the soup, it is ready to serve! Ladle it out into bowls and serve it hot.

tyn: Making Savory Kielbasa and Cabbage Soup
text: Making Savory Kielbasa and Cabbage Soup Melt the butter in a large skillet. Set a skillet on the stove. Add the butter, then turn the heat up to medium. Stir the butter occasionally so that it coats the bottom of the pan. Add the kielbasa, onions, and celery. Cook them, stirring occasionally, until the kielbasa browns. This will take about 3 to 5 minutes. Combine all of the ingredients, except for the potatoes, in a large saucepan. Transfer the browned kielbasa, onions, and celery into a large saucepan. Add the shredded cabbage, sliced carrots, bay leaf, and thyme. Pour in the white vinegar, beef broth, and water. Stir to combine. Hold off on the potatoes for now. You can use prepared beef broth or you can make you own using bouillon cubes and hot water. Typically, it is 1 cube per 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water, but check the package to be certain. Cook the soup for 1 hour. Bring the soup to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. Immediately reduce the heat to low and bring the soup to a simmer. Cover the pot with a lid, and allow the soup to cook for 1 hour. Add the potatoes. Continue cooking the soup until the potatoes turn tender. This will take about 20 minutes, depending on how small you cut the potatoes. Season and serve the soup. Once the potatoes are cooked through, give the soup a taste. Season it with some salt and pepper to your liking, then serve it with a sprinkle of dill. Making Red Kielbasa and Cabbage Soup Heat the oil in a large saucepan over medium heat. As the oil heats, you can start cutting the onions, carrots, potatoes, and kielbasa. The paprika and tomatoes will give this soup a slight, reddish color. Cook the onions, carrots, potatoes, and kielbasa until the onions turn soft. This will take about 5 minutes or so. Stir the ingredients often with a wooden spoon as they cook. This ensures that everything heats evenly. Add in the rest of your ingredients. Toss in the tomatoes and cabbage. Pour in the beef stock. Add in the parsley, sugar, paprika, and pepper. Give everything a good stir to combine. You can use store bought beef stock, or you can prepare you own using hot water and bouillon cubes. Typically, it is 1 cube of bouillon per 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water, but check the packaging to be sure. Bring the soup to a boil, then simmer it for 20 minutes. Cover the saucepan and bring the soup to a boil. Once it starts to boil, lower the heat to medium low. Let the soup simmer for 20 minutes. Keep the saucepan covered during this time. The soup is ready when the vegetables turn tender. Serve the soup. Once the vegetables are tender, ladle the soup out into serving bowls. Serve it while it is still hot. Making Kielbasa and Sauerkraut Soup Prepare the sauerkraut. Take the sauerkraut out of the jar. Transfer it to a strainer, and rinse it under cool water. Allow any excess liquid to drain away, then set the sauerkraut aside. This soup will be a little more tart than the typical kielbasa and cabbage soup. You can make this soup using kielbasa instead of spareribs. Cut the kielbasa into slices. Combine the broth, ribs, bay leaves, peppercorns, carrots, and dried mushrooms in a large saucepan. Hold off on the sauerkraut and sugar for right now. If you can't find any prepared beef broth, you can make your own by dissolving 2 large bouillon cubes in 4 cups (950 milliliters) of hot water. For best flavor, use wild forest mushrooms. If you are using kielbasa, add it in now. Simmer the soup for 1 hour and 30 minutes. Bring the soup to a boil over medium to medium-high heat. Reduce the heat to low. Simmer the soup, uncovered, for 1 hour and 30 minutes. Add 4 more cups (950 milliliters) of water. If you used whole, dried mushrooms, take them out of the pot, cut them into strips, then add them back in. If they are already sliced, you don't need to do this. Heat the sugar over medium heat. Pour the sugar into a separate saucepan. Heat it over medium heat until it starts to caramelize. This will help sweeten the soup and take away some of the tartness. If you don't want to do this, you can skip this step. Add the sauerkraut and sugar to the soup. Give the soup a stir, then let it return to a simmer. Cover the pot with a lid, and let the soup cook for 30 minutes. Slice the ribs up. Take the ribs out of the pot with a pair of tongs. Pull the meat off of the bones using two forks. Cut the meat into bite-sized pieces and return them to the soup. Discard the bones. If you are using kielbasa instead, skip this step. Serve the soup while it is still hot. Once your have the meat back in the soup, it is ready to serve! Ladle it out into bowls and serve it hot.
sentences: Making Savory Kielbasa and Cabbage Soup Melt the butter in a large skillet.
Set a skillet on the stove.
Add the butter, then turn the heat up to medium.
Stir the butter occasionally so that it coats the bottom of the pan.
Add the kielbasa, onions, and celery.
Cook them, stirring occasionally, until the kielbasa browns.
This will take about 3 to 5 minutes.
Combine all of the ingredients, except for the potatoes, in a large saucepan.
Transfer the browned kielbasa, onions, and celery into a large saucepan.
Add the shredded cabbage, sliced carrots, bay leaf, and thyme.
Pour in the white vinegar, beef broth, and water.
Stir to combine.
Hold off on the potatoes for now.
You can use prepared beef broth or you can make you own using bouillon cubes and hot water.
Typically, it is 1 cube per 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water, but check the package to be certain.
Cook the soup for 1 hour.
Bring the soup to a boil over medium to medium-high heat.
Immediately reduce the heat to low and bring the soup to a simmer.
Cover the pot with a lid, and allow the soup to cook for 1 hour.
Add the potatoes.
Continue cooking the soup until the potatoes turn tender.
This will take about 20 minutes, depending on how small you cut the potatoes.
Season and serve the soup.
Once the potatoes are cooked through, give the soup a taste.
Season it with some salt and pepper to your liking, then serve it with a sprinkle of dill.
Making Red Kielbasa and Cabbage Soup Heat the oil in a large saucepan over medium heat.
As the oil heats, you can start cutting the onions, carrots, potatoes, and kielbasa.
The paprika and tomatoes will give this soup a slight, reddish color.
Cook the onions, carrots, potatoes, and kielbasa until the onions turn soft.
This will take about 5 minutes or so.
Stir the ingredients often with a wooden spoon as they cook.
This ensures that everything heats evenly.
Add in the rest of your ingredients.
Toss in the tomatoes and cabbage.
Pour in the beef stock.
Add in the parsley, sugar, paprika, and pepper.
Give everything a good stir to combine.
You can use store bought beef stock, or you can prepare you own using hot water and bouillon cubes.
Typically, it is 1 cube of bouillon per 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water, but check the packaging to be sure.
Bring the soup to a boil, then simmer it for 20 minutes.
Cover the saucepan and bring the soup to a boil.
Once it starts to boil, lower the heat to medium low.
Let the soup simmer for 20 minutes.
Keep the saucepan covered during this time.
The soup is ready when the vegetables turn tender.
Serve the soup.
Once the vegetables are tender, ladle the soup out into serving bowls.
Serve it while it is still hot.
Making Kielbasa and Sauerkraut Soup Prepare the sauerkraut.
Take the sauerkraut out of the jar.
Transfer it to a strainer, and rinse it under cool water.
Allow any excess liquid to drain away, then set the sauerkraut aside.
This soup will be a little more tart than the typical kielbasa and cabbage soup.
You can make this soup using kielbasa instead of spareribs.
Cut the kielbasa into slices.
Combine the broth, ribs, bay leaves, peppercorns, carrots, and dried mushrooms in a large saucepan.
Hold off on the sauerkraut and sugar for right now.
If you can't find any prepared beef broth, you can make your own by dissolving 2 large bouillon cubes in 4 cups (950 milliliters) of hot water.
For best flavor, use wild forest mushrooms.
If you are using kielbasa, add it in now.
Simmer the soup for 1 hour and 30 minutes.
Bring the soup to a boil over medium to medium-high heat.
Reduce the heat to low.
Simmer the soup, uncovered, for 1 hour and 30 minutes.
Add 4 more cups (950 milliliters) of water.
If you used whole, dried mushrooms, take them out of the pot, cut them into strips, then add them back in.
If they are already sliced, you don't need to do this.
Heat the sugar over medium heat.
Pour the sugar into a separate saucepan.
Heat it over medium heat until it starts to caramelize.
This will help sweeten the soup and take away some of the tartness.
If you don't want to do this, you can skip this step.
Add the sauerkraut and sugar to the soup.
Give the soup a stir, then let it return to a simmer.
Cover the pot with a lid, and let the soup cook for 30 minutes.
Slice the ribs up.
Take the ribs out of the pot with a pair of tongs.
Pull the meat off of the bones using two forks.
Cut the meat into bite-sized pieces and return them to the soup.
Discard the bones.
If you are using kielbasa instead, skip this step.
Serve the soup while it is still hot.
Once your have the meat back in the soup, it is ready to serve!
Ladle it out into bowls and serve it hot.
